description: From German Neotenie, coined in 1884 by anatomist Julius Kollmann from Ancient Greek νέος (néos, “young”) + τείνειν (teínein, “to tense”).

entries.meaning: (biology) The retention of juvenile characteristics in the adult.
examples: Most amphibians are aquatic only while young, but some amphibians with neoteny remain aquatic even as adults.

entries.meaning: (biology) The sexual maturity of an organism still in its larval stage.
